The structure of hydrate is also important for the application of hydrate as a carbon dioxide storage method. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and low temperature. The structure of neon hydrate is different from that of conventional hydrate, which is ice-like. The structure of neon hydrate is also different from that of ice II, which is the most stable ice structure at ambient pressure and temperature.

The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of current debate. A number of reconstruction programs have been proposed, each of which attempts to provide a foundation for quantum theory in terms of a more familiar mathematical structure. In this paper, we provide a categorical foundation for quantum theory. Our approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. They are also the sister group to the group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two species of myxozoans, which are distantly related, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian. This reduction was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. (Show more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused more than 100 million infections and more than 2 million deaths worldwide. The virus responsible for this pandemic, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), is able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Here, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this evasion mechanism. We also show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that is essential for nuclear import. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the viral antagonism mechanism and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s food production will have to increase by 70% by 2050 to meet the needs of a projected 9 billion people. This increase will be challenging, especially in the tropics, where the optimum growing temperature is exceeded in many years. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level food-plant consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study provides a framework for understanding the role of LMH in the structure and functioning of African savanna ecosystems. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely differing beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The age of the Solar System is a key issue in astronomy. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. These results provide constraints on the formation of the Solar System and the evolution of the early interstellar medium. They also provide a new method to determine the age of presolar grains.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother is a key factor in the success of all species that practice allonursing. Here, we show that the practice of allonursing, in which a nonbreeding female provides care to a young offspring of a different breeding female, is associated with increased reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the amount of resources available to the mother rather than an increase in the number of litters produced. This result suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is the mother’s metabolic power. This finding has important implications for the evolution of all forms of allonursing and the evolution of domestication. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a rare neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is sporadic, and no treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation.

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines the interior surface of blood vessels. It is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. The endothelium controls vascular function, including the control of blood pressure, the regulation of inflammation, and the control of blood flow. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to respond to a wide variety of stimuli. It does so by the coordinated activity of a large number of cells. Here, we show that the endothelial network is a small-world network, which is a property of networks that is associated with high efficiency in the transmission of information. This finding provides insight into the design of the endothelial network and its role in the control of cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic and for responding to it effectively. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a valuable resource for the global community. We hope that it will be useful to researchers, policymakers, and the public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the targets of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and for the C-type inactivation gating. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a molecular understanding of the allosteric coupling in potassium channels. It also provides a molecular basis for the C-type inactivation gating and for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter. This work may lead to the development of new drugs and to the design of new potassium-channel-based biosensors.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host animal and the plant diet. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host animal is not fully understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is important for the health of the animal. This study provides a resource of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the digestive tracts of herbivores. These fungi are important members of the gut microbiome and are often overlooked in studies of the microbiome. This study provides a resource of natural products that could be used to understand the role of anaerobic fungi in the health of herbivores.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups and is influenced by personality traits. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also identify a potential avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders by showing that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens can be targeted to improve social behavior. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures that can realize arbitrary and extreme responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis approach to discover optimal multimaterial composite structures that can seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The structures are digitally synthesized and effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. They exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. It also provides a platform for the design of mechanical devices with complex and navigable responses. This work is expected to inspire the design of mechanical structures and devices with desired responses. The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in the let-7 pathway. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the developing human fetus and is highly expressed in the erythroid lineage. We also show that IGF2BP1 can reverse the adult hemoglobin profile in primary human erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important in the development of hemoglobin disorders and in the regulation of hemoglobin levels in response to environmental factors.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway protects cancer cells from oxidative stress and ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1. Finally, we showed that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide a rationale for the development of new therapies for cancer, which are effective against both mTORC1-dependent and -independent pathways. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Our study shows that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. It also provides a potential target for the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases. (Read more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet succeeded in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem, which is the focus of the recently proposed Forest Plan revision, is not a panacea for the conservation of early-seral bird species.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work provides a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the rational design of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the number of parameters required to achieve accurate results is often high. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that consists of a single set of operations. The proposed architecture is easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is thus a promising tool for applications in computer vision and image processing. The code is available at this https URL .

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. However, the biological effects of such devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin secretion and reduces alertness the following morning, compared with reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climate event that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases is complex and depends on the stage of life at which the deficiency is induced.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive view of the evolution of beetles, including the origins of their feeding habits, and show that the evolution of their ability to digest plant cell walls may have been key to the diversification of this group.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population was inversely related to CCE. This finding is important because it suggests that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of cultural artifacts. We also found that the greater variation participants had access to in the larger populations may have overwhelmed their working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the evolution of culture in general. They also have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the evolution of culture. Finally, our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apoE allele, APOE4. APOE is a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type of the central nervous system. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes and suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies also provide a rationale for the use of APOE as a biomarker for AD risk. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is likely to have formed by a two-step nucleation process, which is a new scenario for the inner core formation.

We present a large-scale, integrative modeling study of the human brain and language. We find that the most powerful artificial neural network models of the brain, trained on vast amounts of data, capture the essence of the language comprehension system. This suggests that the language comprehension system is well-suited for computational modeling and that the brain’s use of recurrent connections is critical for efficient computation of the high-dimensional language input. These results provide computational evidence for the fundamental role of language in the human mind.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still an open problem to develop a rigorous theory of DL. We provide a classification theory of DL, which describes the conditions under which one can compute a stable neural network (NN) with a given accuracy. We prove that, for some well-conditioned problems in scientific computing, there does not exist any algorithm that can compute a NN with a given accuracy. This result is a step toward a rigorous understanding of the stability of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the health care system, and the failure of people to follow the rules. In this paper, we argue that the failure of people to follow the rules is also due to a failure of science. We discuss a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago, which is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We show that the experiment’s critical design flaws were not recognized at the time, and that they led to the wrong conclusion. We conclude with a discussion of the implications of this unique case study for the study of human behavior.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of it has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the leprosy bacillus. We found that the two organisms are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation, and that they are still capable of causing similar diseases. This study provides a framework for future studies of the evolution of leprosy. (Read more)

The evolution of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a key open problem in quantum physics. Here, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the limit of most interest. We do so by combining integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. This result provides a powerful tool for the study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide class of quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in humans is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech. This vaccine is expensive, requires refrigeration, and has a limited shelf life. In this study, we describe a vaccine that is easy to manufacture, can be stored at room temperature, and has a long shelf life. This vaccine is based on a modified version of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is currently in clinical development.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for understanding the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The evolution of the brain is the most important factor in the rise of complex cognition. However, the evolution of brain size as a proxy for the evolution of brain power is biased by the fact that brains of different species are compared by their mass. This study shows that, by using the number of neurons, we can get a less biased picture of the evolution of brain power. We show that the evolution of brain size is not only a function of body size but also of the evolution of the number of neurons. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the utility of current inhibitors is limited by their ability to distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, a chaperone that is also overexpressed in many cancers. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This may have implications for the development of TRAP1-directed therapies. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by severing the filaments. However, how it does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to the filament and induces a mechanical torque, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that this mechanism is a general principle of ADF action. Our findings have implications for understanding ADF’s role in cell motility and cancer. They also have potential applications in biomaterials and biomechanics.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island has been colonized by different waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The distribution of the genomic diversity across the island shows that the colonization was not homogeneous, and that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but happened in several waves. The distribution of the genomic diversity also shows that the island has been influenced by the genetic diversity of the continent, and that the genetic diversity of Madagascar is not as unique as previously thought. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for the interpretation of the genetic diversity of human populations, and for the interpretation of the history of Madagascar.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred via social networks. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is a critical determinant of translation, but the ribosome can also be influenced by the chemical modifications present in the mRNA. In this work, we show that the most common mRNA modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a significant impact on translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in translation and the development of therapeutic strategies for diseases caused by mutations in translation machinery components.
