This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a central theme in the history of life. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been studied in cell culture, but the underlying mechanisms have not been elucidated. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These results provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (Read more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the surface-associated type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the pili. This results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment to the surface and the expression of virulence factors. This is an example of how bacteria can use their motility system for both motility and sensing. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of motility systems in bacteria and the regulation of virulence. They also have potential applications in the development of new strategies for controlling bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the biological integrity of global water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the pandemic is less well understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a free-living animal species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 has spread between deer and humans in Iowa. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of animals in the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of this trend and the challenges that need to be addressed. We find that the benefits of hydropower are often overestimated and the costs underestimated. We also find that the environmental and social impacts of dams are often not considered in the decision-making process. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary focus of current research. However, the immune response in AD is not solely attributed to Aβ, and we show that soluble Aβ species are not the only toxic amyloid species that can trigger an inflammatory response. We demonstrate that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are also vulnerable to Aβ toxicity and can produce a variety of potent inflammatory factors. These factors correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This finding may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD. (Read more)

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is a story of a species that was first domesticated in the Near East, and then spread to Europe, where it became a major source of protein for the human diet. The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe is dated to the first century B.C.E. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the Near East is still unknown. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which provides the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the Near East. The results of our survey of the Southern Levant further suggest that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry predates the evidence from the Near East by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken. (Abridged)

We have studied the folding of the large maltose binding protein (MBP) at high structural resolution by an advanced hydrogen-exchange method. The results show that the folding of MBP is a multistep process. The folding intermediates are structurally distinct and are not the same as the native state. The results also show that the folding of large proteins is more complex than previously thought.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the levels of this class of molecules remain largely unknown. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to be the predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, is the primary enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs in Escherichia coli. We also show that RppH prefers to decape Np4-capped RNAs over their counterparts that are capped only with a single phosphate. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of Np4 in bacterial stress response and gene expression. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that affects millions of people worldwide. Despite the availability of effective antibiotics, the mortality rate remains high. The mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of citrulline as a potential therapeutic strategy for sepsis. View Full-Text

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet, and that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the global biomass of humans has increased by a factor of 100 since the beginning of the Common Era. These findings provide a global perspective on the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They also highlight the importance of humans in the history of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves to a critical state, in which it is not possible to predict the future behavior from the past, but the system is robust with respect to small perturbations. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, it is not easy to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic bandgap can be completely vanished, by applying strain. This finding can be used to control the properties of diamond.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a major focus of research in the field of peptide science. This work provides a structural and functional characterization of a unique peptide, NCR044, from the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. The structure of the peptide was determined by NMR spectroscopy, and it was found to be highly dynamic and largely disordered. The peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It bound to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. The peptide was shown to penetrate the fungal cell wall and membrane, followed by accumulation in the cytoplasm and nucleoli of germlings. The work provides a structural and functional characterization of a unique peptide, NCR044, from the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula, and it paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. (Read more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the female reproductive tract makes contributions to the development of the male gametes. However, the extent of such contributions is largely unknown. Here, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a key player in the blood clotting process. In some people, mutations in VWF cause a bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD. This work provides a quantitative understanding of the role of force in the regulation of VWF. It also provides a framework for understanding other proteins that are regulated by force.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and uses it to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results provide a foundation for future studies of the human virome, and may lead to the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. This instrument is capable of measuring aerosol and cloud properties with high spatial and temporal resolution. We use this instrument to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature inferred from isotopic data is in broad agreement with the temperature inferred from protein reconstruction, but the isotopic record may be subject to uncertainties. We here present a method for determining the paleotemperature of ancient organisms based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes reconstructed from ancient and modern organisms. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Abridged)

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the regulation of K+ channel gating and C-type inactivation. They also suggest that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may also provide a basis for the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmia. (Read more)

Malaria is a devastating disease that affects millions of people each year. The Plasmodium parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the parasite’s surface proteins in this process has been the subject of intense investigation. Here, we show that the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This may have implications for the development of new therapies for malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Therefore, it is important to control its properties by external stimuli. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering. This finding offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza prevention and treatment. (Read more)

The brain is thought to build a tree-like syntactic structure of a sentence word by word, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results suggest that the brain implements a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. They also provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. These results have implications for our understanding of the brain’s processing of language. They also suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and disease. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the canonical Wnt pathway. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a deeper understanding of the regulation of redundant genes and their role in tissue-specific function. It also provides a model for the study of other redundant gene pairs.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we provide a detailed characterization of the brain circuitry that promotes overeating in mice. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the circuit that promotes overeating and may contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is a key nutrient for plant growth and productivity, but its availability is often a limiting factor. In agriculture, the majority of N is applied in the form of inorganic fertilizer, but this approach is unsustainable and inefficient. In this work, we demonstrate a method to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria, using a synthetic signaling circuit. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in agricultural settings, with the potential to improve the efficiency of N use and reduce the environmental impact of agriculture. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. The program was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. Vaccine development has been rapid, and several vaccines are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. This study reports a recombinant protein that can be expressed in large quantities in microbial cells, with high affinity for the virus entry receptor, and with enhanced immunogenicity compared to the currently used Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence. This engineered protein can be presented on a virus-like particle to reduce weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results provide a potential vaccine candidate for global access. (Show more)

The small ALKAL proteins are implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In this study, we show that the small ALKAL proteins are ligands for the ALK/LTK receptor family in the zebrafish. We further show that the ALKALs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of the ALKALs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This knowledge will be important for the development of zebrafish models for human ALK/LTK receptor-related diseases.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has caused devastating outbreaks throughout human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-established story. However, the number of ancient Y. pestis genomes is too small to explore its diversity during the critical period of its evolution. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which allowed us to explore the temporal and geographical patterns of its evolution. We find that the plague bacterium underwent a series of evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Y. pseudotuberculosis-like ancestor, and that it underwent rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and the role of masculinity in the 2020 presidential election.

The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural systems is a key determinant of global climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to massive C losses to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems to sequester C on grasslands has not been well-characterized. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate legumes and manure into annual cropping systems can increase soil C storage and the use of soil C by microbes. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester C and provide a framework for climate-smart agriculture. This work also highlights the importance of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a framework for systematically identifying and prioritizing viruses of greatest concern for spillover and spread in humans. It also provides a platform for the public to access and contribute to the ongoing assessment of viral threats to human health. This is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators and is often used as a proxy for the quality of the reward. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this color in other plants. This work provides a molecular understanding of the evolution of a color that is likely to be a key trait in the evolution of plant–pollinator interactions.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from the late 5th/early 6th century AD, who lived in present-day Bavaria, Germany. Our data indicate that the men of this group had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may help to develop effective vaccines and therapeutics for MERS-CoV. These results also suggest that bat coronaviruses may be a potential threat to human health in the future. (Show more)

The global pandemic of COVID-19 has highlighted the need for rapid, accurate, and scalable pathogen surveillance. Here, we demonstrate the feasibility of using metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in Cambodia. Our findings suggest that mNGS can be used to rapidly identify the regional pathogen landscape and surveillance of emerging pathogens in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to rapidly deploy public health response to emerging pathogens.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of DNA strands in the 3′ to 5′ direction. This process is known as DNA replication and is essential for the proper functioning of all living organisms. The process is carried out by a complex of proteins and enzymes, known as the replisome. This study provides a detailed analysis of the structure and function of the human replisome.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate and convert RNA templates into functional RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world, in which life was thought to have originated.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately, and reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes is not. We demonstrate that the xan BGC-derived isocyanide metabolites of Aspergillus fumigatus bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi may be a mechanism for the regulation of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the control of interactions with competing microbes. (Read more)

The formation of silica in the martian interior is a key to understanding the evolution of the planet. Silica is a major component of the Martian surface and interior materials, and it is a key component of the atmosphere. Silica is also a major component of the organic molecules that have been detected on the surface and in the atmosphere. Silica is a major component of the life we know. Silica is a major component of the life we do not know.

The impact of late-spring frosts (LSFs) on plants and animals is widespread and economically important. However, the geographic distribution of LSFs and the evolutionary impact of these frosts on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is linked to the leaf-out strategies of trees, and that the increasing frequency of LSFs in some regions is likely to increase frost damage. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a recently identified subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to Th17 cells are not well understood. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both the IL-12 and the IFN-γ receptor, but that the expression of the transcription factor T-bet is not required. We also show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important for the development of disease in inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We have developed a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and identify therapeutic targets. We found that motor neurons are highly sensitive to astrocyte-derived toxicity, and this toxicity is shared between ALS patients with different genetic causes. This method will enable rapid screening of drugs to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity and accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. This work will also help to understand the role of astrocytes in other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates pathogen colonization. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan pentapeptide chain, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of arthropod vectors and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin and early evolution of the short-tailed bird group are poorly understood. Here, we describe a new species of early pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This species adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group and the evolution of the avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the system without a detailed understanding of the processes that are occurring within it. In this paper, we show that the behavior of the climate system can be understood in terms of a number of simple processes.

The evolution of color in animals is a topic of great interest, but the biochemical basis of the phenomenon is poorly understood. Here, we describe the biochemical basis of the evolution of green color in frogs. We show that the occurrence of green color in frogs has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the green color of frogs is due to the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is normally present in the blood. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of green color in frogs and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. These results also provide a model for the evolution of color in vertebrates. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer cells are characterized by the ability to form cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for the initiation and progression of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the ALKBH5 demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a key factor in the maintenance of CSCs. This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the development of CSCs, which may be targeted for the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Read more)

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the production of parchment was a complex process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This process may have been possible because of the tissue-thin nature of the parchment.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction and its aftermath. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction, and the recovery was rapid. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. They also provide a basis for evaluating the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction and its aftermath. (Abridged as above)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and the circadian rhythm. Here, we report the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific deletion of RORα (RORαΔIEC) in mice. We find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in the open conformation, which is associated with the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G spike is more open than the wild-type spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. These results provide insight into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Fudenberg and Levine (1985) on finite games. Our proof is simpler than the proof of Fudenberg and Levine, and it applies to games with countably infinite sets of players and action sets. Our result is also a step toward the study of repeated games with continuous payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings highlight the disproportionate impact of COVID-19 on racial and ethnic minorities and the need to address the social determinants of health. (Read more)

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We also show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales can be used to predict and explain the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. This work provides a new perspective on the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. It also provides a new way to understand the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. It is a major advance in the field of chemical physics.

Fire is a key climate-driven disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems, but its future trajectory is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting 5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights that ignitions and fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate.

The provision of nutrients to microbes associated with animals is a common feature of the animal–microbe interactions. However, the timing and nature of such provision is often unknown. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent bacterium. We also show that the glycan is provided only at night, and that the glycan catabolism is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and the periodic acidification of the symbiont habitat. These results suggest that the timing and nature of nutrient provision may be a general feature of symbiosis. This may be a mechanism by which animals can control the activities of their symbionts. Such control may be important for the health of the host and the symbiont. (Read more)

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly being used to understand the world around us. However, the latent patterns in text data are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent patterns in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to a wide range of domains and can be extended to other types of data. We believe that this approach will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. These results provide a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its impact on human history. (Abridged)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a rapidly spreading disease that has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the sea stars themselves. The virus is present in the plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that it can spread over long distances. The virus has been present on the Pacific Coast for at least 72 y, suggesting that it has been spreading undetected for a long time. The virus is therefore the most promising candidate disease agent responsible for the mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This work provides a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. This approach could be extended to other

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island has been colonized by different waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the colonization was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a tool to study the history of human populations in a new way, with a focus on the island as a unique case. It also provides a tool to study the history of human populations in a new way, with a focus on the island as a unique case.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings provide insight into the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the risk of viral escape and the emergence of new variants. Our approach may also be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and drugs. Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s Crop Progress and Condition survey, which collects expert assessments of crop status, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used in quantitative analyses. We show that the survey data are stable over time, and that they can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of the survey data to provide a more complete picture of the state of agriculture in the United States. This can be extended to other countries and crops to provide a more complete picture of the state of agriculture around the world.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Abridged)

The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a key factor in the evolution of the plant kingdom. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is accompanied by a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. We present a model of the evolutionary trajectory of the plastid genome during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are a direct measure of the functional reduction of the plastid genome. This evolutionary signature can be used to infer the evolutionary history of the plant kingdom. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional climate models in the assessment of anthropogenic climate change. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the creation of the first nuclear bomb.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is accomplished by the capture of light by pigments, the conversion of light energy to chemical energy, and the storage of this energy in the form of ATP and NADPH. The biosynthesis of the pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. This work shows that the oxygenic phototrophs have a different cyclase enzyme than the anoxygenic phototrophs, and that the cyclase is divided into three classes. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this important pathway. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (Read more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most severe droughts in the historical record. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities. This finding is important because it suggests that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability of drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis. The genetic variants of several hundred risk genes are thought to contribute to the disorder. However, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. Here, we show that behavioral flexibility, which is a measure of the ability to forget, is a converging target of the autism-risk genes. We found that the loss of function of five autism-risk genes all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This finding provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism. It also provides a target for drug development. (Read more)

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the prevalence of negativity biases in news content on a global scale. It finds that, on average, news content is more negative than entertainment content, and that this is the case across 17 countries and 6 continents. It also finds that individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is considerable. This work thus helps account for the prevalence of negative news content, and it also highlights the potential for more positive content. It suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the STIM1 Ca2+ sensor that result in a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities. We also identify mutations in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the molecular basis of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates, which is in turn dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is thought to protect them from infection. However, the immune system of bats is not immune to infection. Here, we identified a protein, MTX, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential explanation for the emergence of viral diseases in bats and the subsequent spillover to humans and other animals. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key regulator of cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used it to identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. We show that cancer cells are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition, and that this sensitivity is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease that affects motor neurons and is caused by a variety of genetic mutations. These mutations lead to the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies that contain a number of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We observe that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is a step toward the development of a 2D photonic crystal system for quantum information processing. This work is a step toward the development of a 2D photonic crystal system for quantum information processing.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic and may have been very common at an early stage of evolution. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, provides new insights into the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using genetic sequences from modern viruses. However, the evolutionary history of viruses can be reconstructed from ancient viral sequences as well. Here we present the genomes of five ancient human parvoviruses, which are the oldest viral sequences found to date. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that ancient viral sequences can be used to study the evolution of viruses in the distant past. This is important for understanding the evolution of viruses and their impact on human health. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. These changes are the result of a complex interplay of natural and human factors. The dominant natural factor is the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, which is expected to continue for the foreseeable future. The dominant human factor is the increase in the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere, which is caused by human activities, such as the burning of fossil fuels.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been greater for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader trend of decline in the quality of life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This picture reveals the fate of the leaving group in the reaction back to the preceding transition state, and it provides a mechanism for the reaction. The study also highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into the chemical dynamics of enzyme active sites. This work demonstrates the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) remains a major public health concern, with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

We also show that the glycan is provided only at night, and that the glycan catabolism is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and the periodic acidification of the symbiont habitat. These results suggest that the timing and nature of nutrient provision may be a general feature of symbiosis. This may be a mechanism by which animals can control the activities of their symbionts. Such control may be important for the health of the host and the symbiont. (Read more)

This paper describes a series of experiments that tested whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline could be changed. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. This has important implications for the future of American schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct pol II stalling profiles, and the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will help us to understand the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and provide a basis for the development of novel strategies for the prevention and treatment of human diseases.
