Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe respiratory disease in humans. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of the S proteins is required for virus infection, and that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. These findings may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and is a leading cause of biodiversity loss and water pollution. The food system also has a major impact on population health. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that can be implemented in a wide range of settings. We also show that the intervention had no detectable rebound effects. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a framework for understanding the cell surface proteome in cancer cells. It also provides a platform for drug and biomarker discovery. (Read more)

In response to the coronavirus pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail programs are not likely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune response and to interfere with the host interferon response. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. We show that the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 is similar to SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may be used to mediate immune suppression and evasion activities. These results provide insight into the mechanisms of the virus and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this potentially life-threatening illness. (Read more)

The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. This is the idea of “selective inference”: We should only accept as true statements those that are supported by a large body of evidence. In the era of big data, however, it is difficult to avoid cherry-picking the strongest associations. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help scientists to avoid the pitfalls of overconfidence and overinterpretation. We also hope that this will help policy makers to avoid the pitfalls of overreaction and overreach.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordination of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified a transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2), that induces the development of vascular ECs from nonvascular cells. This finding provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and the development of vascular regeneration. Furthermore, the use of ETV2-expressing cells in transplantation therapy provides a new strategy for the treatment of vascular disorders. These findings will contribute to the development of new therapies for vascular disorders. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand for a RTK is a key step in understanding the physiological role of the RTK. In this study, we show that the ligand of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) ALK is encoded by two genes, ALKAL1 and ALKAL2. We also show that the ligand of the other orphan RTK, Ltk, is encoded by three genes. We demonstrate that the ligand of Ltk is essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophore system. These findings establish a physiological link between ALK and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of RTKs in development and disease. (Read more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is required for the maintenance of insulin secretion in β-cells. We also found that STING is decreased in islets of diabetic mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings also provide a potential target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We show that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A virus, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging mechanism of influenza A virus. They also provide a basis for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular cells. The objective of this study is to identify the mechanisms that regulate the development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Read more)

Wildfires are a natural and important part of the ecosystem, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and to other types of data to further our understanding of urban change. Our code is available at https://github.com/jwang112/neighborhood-improvement.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and it should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It also exemplifies the arthropod–plant adaptation. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The virus replicates rapidly within cells, and the time between infection and production of infectious virus is unknown. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. Finally, we assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, ultimately leading to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a primary site of tumorigenesis. We demonstrate that the tumorigenic response leads to the dysregulation of the microbiome, which in turn triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for cancer and the microbiome. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in host–microbe homeostasis and host–microbiome interactions. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of the microbiome in host–microbe homeostasis and host–microbiome interactions. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in host–microbe homeostasis and host–microbiome interactions.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the most common cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is variable, and many patients relapse. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to reestablish tumors in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reestablish tumors in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is not supported by a unique volcanic eruption. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation is instead linked to a series of massive volcanic eruptions from Mount Takahe, Antarctica, that led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate response similar to that of modern ozone depletion over Antarctica.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Fish richness and catches are positively but not causally correlated, revealing that fishing pressure is most intense in rivers where potential impacts on biodiversity are highest. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in the C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the canonical DLK-1/DLK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory neuron and is enhanced by disrupting calcium signaling. We also identify a form of regeneration in the mammalian CNS that is triggered by sensory stimulation and is enhanced by elevating cAMP levels. These findings suggest that the mechanisms that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system are conserved across species. This study also provides a platform for the discovery of novel genes that control the regulation of the adult nervous system’s regenerative capacity. Together, these findings advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the nervous system.

The process of meiosis is critical for the production of genetically diverse gametes, and the distribution of recombination events across the genome is a key determinant of the efficiency of meiosis. Here, we present a detailed map of recombination events in a flowering plant, which provides insights into the evolution of the process.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The present study provides a method to identify and validate resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. The method is based on the analysis of metabolic imaging, which maps nonfluctuating signals related to total neuronal activity. The method was applied to healthy subjects and Parkinson’s disease patients, and the results were compared with those obtained from functional MRI. The results provide a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. The method can be used to identify and validate the functional significance of the networks, and to assess their functional changes in disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. In bacteria, a second modification, 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+), has been described. Whether this modification exists in eukaryotes is unknown. We show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This finding defines an additional 5′ modification in eukaryotes and raises the possibility that the 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for understanding the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. (Read more)

Diabetes metabolic memory is the phenomenon of the long-term beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood are maintained for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and persist for several years after the end of the DCCT in people with diabetes. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and has no targeted therapy. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 is required for the growth of TNBC cells in vitro and in vivo and that it promotes autophagy, which in turn, inhibits chemotherapy sensitivity. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic, relapsing, and progressive disease that affects the brain and the gut. The brain is the organ that is most affected by alcohol, and it is the organ that is most difficult to treat. The gut is the organ that is least affected by alcohol, and it is the organ that is most difficult to study. In this study, we show that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, and that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is a key feature of fruit ripening. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of a large number of VOCs in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of VOCs and opens the way for the development of improved tomato cultivars. (Read more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We also show that the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance traits of species. Our results highlight that biodiversity loss, independent of the species’ thermal tolerance traits, will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This finding has important implications for the future functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems and the services they provide.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is critical for spatial memory. The organization of MEC is not well understood, in part because of a lack of methods to study the structure and function of neurons in vivo. Here, we developed a method to record from and image the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We used this method to study the organization of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and adjacent parasubiculum. Our results suggest that the organization of grid cells is distinct from that of border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings will help to advance our understanding of the function of MEC in spatial memory. (Read more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for the flowering of the host and the parasite. This finding illustrates the importance of FTs as an important interplant flowering signal. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a unique example of the evolution of flowering regulation in plants.

The dopamine-containing system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing system of the brain is highly integrated, with striosomes receiving input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and linking functionally to reinforcement and decision-making. We also show that the dopamine-containing system of the brain is highly complex, with striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes forming highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed with which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. Within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This is a fundamental property of social connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its function is tightly regulated. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the function of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice from insect attack. This study also provides a model for understanding the interaction between Si and JA in plant defense. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings may have implications for the treatment of phenylketonuria and other diseases.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of different DNA nanostructures for their ability to internalize into cells of mature plants, deliver siRNAs, and effectively silence a constitutively expressed gene in Nicotiana benthamiana leaves. We show that nanostructure internalization into plant cells and corresponding gene silencing efficiency depends on the DNA nanostructure size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure. We further confirm that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step forward in the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are also among the most vulnerable to nutrient pollution. We show that the nutrient inputs to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, are driven by a small number of large tributaries. However, the nutrient inputs from small tributaries are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that nutrient inputs from small watersheds may be more important than previously thought in fueling algal blooms in nearshore areas of large lakes. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal nutrient pollution and provide a framework for targeting nutrient management efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution in large lakes.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of a mechanical system that is driven by a random force. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of chemical networks that can operate in the presence of strong environmental forcing.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities by changing the dynamics of the brain. This is a major advance in our understanding of the mechanisms of this disease, which is currently incurable. Our findings also have implications for the treatment of this disease.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system. However, the history of C-perturbed events is poorly understood, especially for the past 100 Ma. Here, we present a study of a C-perturbed event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the ocean floor. Our results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the role of organic matter in the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate commitments to reduce this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been quantified. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia by 33% from 2001 to 2015. Nevertheless, most plantations were already deforested by 2015, and certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the need for certification to be tightly linked to effective land-use planning and enforcement.

The exocyst complex is a key regulator of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles are segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles, one of which determines sex, also produce siblings with four possible sex classes. We find that polygenic sex determination produces an interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation resulting in modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by a number of factors that can lead to the accumulation of reactive oxygen species and damage to the photoreceptor cells. We sought to understand the role of iron in the retina and found that iron levels can influence the levels of a class of molecules that are important for the health of the retina.

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentilla has strong associations with prey type, and that these associations are linked to the evolution of the tentilla themselves. Our findings help to understand the evolution of predator specialization, and how it has shaped the structure of present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is incomplete, however, and the origin of some of the key features of the modern hand is unclear. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key feature of the human hand, was present in a fossil from East Africa that lived ∼1.42 million years ago. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This fossil provides a key link in the evolution of the human hand. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key regulator of cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used it to identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. We show that cancer cells are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition, and that this sensitivity is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this can be mitigated by the presence of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
